With the Mars settlement; journey time is going to be the biggest obstacle; even if we accelerate at 3 g's to half the speed of light would take him two and a half months. Even at 9 g's, it would take nineteen days to reach half the speed of light; which we can only survive if we have learned to manipulate inertia. That being said, if option 1 & 2 are possible, if we could get up to speed would we have time to stop? If no, assuming we haven’t cracked inertia; what is the quickest possible time (and Max’d speed) to allow accelerate and de-accelerate to arrive at Mars with human settlers?

During WWII so many cargo ships were being sunk by German submarines that a new super cheap cargo ship needed to be produced in huge quantities. In the US these came to be known as Liberty Ships and 2,710 were produced in just 4 years. At a an absolute minimum Spacex has designed a Liberty Ship for LEO and this by itself is a monumental achievement. This reduction in cost of a kg to LEO could very well be the tipping point that makes large scale commercialization of space possible.

Is SpaceX running a testing campaign on a Raptor engine to determine reliability and re-usability? This could be done through repeated ground tests and inspections and does not require the full hardware stack. Just firing the engine for full duration runs, and firing with repeated restarts. The Starship assumes rapid reflight. It will be a while before they are ready to fly starships multiple times. They should take advantage of the airframe prototyping time to improve the engine capability.

Very exciting and a great achievement - a true milestone.  That being said I saw two anomalies.  First the fire within the plumbing of the Raptor engine.  Second - there appeared to be an explosion on the ground just after liftoff which threw up shrapnel and debris.  The debris can be spotted from LabPadre's video, but the explosion can be seen on the drone footage - looks like the explosion threw up the debris and may have in fact caused the fire on the Raptor.   Not sure.  What are your thoughts?

This was so totally awesome. While looking at this I was noticing however the area taken up by the raptor engine from space x's overview video. It didn't look to me that 31 raptors could fit in that skirt. So I did some quick math comparing areas, the raptor area to the total available area provided by the 9 meter can. Not even taking into account volumes just a 1.4 meter(at widest point) raptor and piRsquare that to get its area and do the same for the 9 meter area and divide the can calculated available area by the raptor calculated area, and I get 13 as the total number raptor engines that can fit? Hopefully someone can check my math on that but it doesn't seem to me that 31 engines can come close to fitting even if staggered.Of course I'm speaking of the booster and not the starship but I believe they have the same diameter? Again hopefully someone can correct my math :) In any event however Elon is going to do this I am totally stoked for the next phase!

This is what happens when people really get together, not just with the vague notion of being profitable for themselves somehow, but with a specific vision of a future they are dedicated to making come to life. That's when the magic happens.

Sure, they will also make some money, because they are creating a future where what they believe in becomes as important to others as it is to themselves. In fact, they will make more money, because they have a reason to be there, fully imbedded in that future, while others are stumbling about still looking for some purpose.

This is the magic. It's the willpower and personal resources of a lot of people who are focused together on making a change in reality -- a new reality. The spell you cast is the work you do to achieve it:

-- The magic wand is your designing pen.
-- The magical chalice is your coffee cup as you work late to finish each stage of the plan.
-- The magic swords are your tools that cut and shape and form the substances that will embody your ideas in physical form, even digital forms.
-- The magic staff is each others shoulders that you all lean on from time to time, when you are weary, to give each other the strength to persevere when the task is long and hard.
-- The magical cauldron is the iron-clad shell of your collective resolve into which all the ingredients go, and where all your tools and components must work, in order to produce the final manifestations you desire.

This is the witchcraft of engineering; and it can take you from what you hope is possible, to what you can produce as inevitable. This is how magic changes the world.

+ + + + +

The Apprentice Sorceress:

She was studying hard at her formulas, memorizing ingredients, learning names, kept company only by the irregular "tick... snick... scrape... taptaptap" of her teacher chipping away at a small, brittle rock.
"So what is the magic, really?" she asked him.
He looked up, apparently surprised and yet not, winked to her, and gave his apprentice the answer that worked:
"Oh, THE magic? Magic is what happens when you use the training of your mind, the skills of your hands, and the communions of your heart to transform the world. It is all the powers you have made of yourself that did not come by instinct, nor events by accident. Whether you are growing a garden outside or banishing a demon from within, that's the magic."
He handed her the symmetrically-faceted, razor-sharp, flint-knapped arrowhead he had been gradually flaking down to a fine point for an hour, and reminded her:
"Sometimes you see a thing done so many times, for so long a history, that you forget it is magic. You call it a trade or a craft, and don't notice that it is still changing and ruling your world every day. You get so good at it, so automatic, that you may lose your love and awe of it. You're just making a clay pot, you might say, just weaving cloth or carving wood.
"These are the very things that have most defined your world already. If you wish to be able to re-define it in some way, you have to remember how much magic is already at work, so that you may recruit those magics -- and the masters of them -- to your side as well. From this, a whole city may be summoned upon the world!
"Never underestimate how the magics may build upon themselves, and upon each other. Now string that arrowhead up on a necklace. You will wear it until you make one better. That is how you truly test your magic... not by your intentions, but by your results."

It's now several hours past liftoff and it's just starting to sink in. The implications...
1. Raptor engines are no longer experimental. These things work and they work well.
2. A single tiny Raptor can hoist a grain silo 150m in the air and fly around with it under excellent control.
3. All those shock diamonds... was this Raptor anywhere near its optimum altitude for efficiency?
4. If SpaceX can do this, it may imply they have solved the bulk of the problems that stand between them and an operational Starship. I'd like comments on this one.
I'm quite young (15), so I can imagine myself buying starship ticket to mars in the near future and sitting on that beast!

My theory on the engine fire and debris at launch...

Turn a torch lighter upside while lit without quickly moving away... Multiply that by about what, a million? This is essentially a giant torch lighter hardly moving so all the heat that would typically be displaced by the upward momentum, couldn't really go anywhere and likely just ignited some taping or piping insulation. Or, hold the engine at 4500 rpm on your car for half an hour (if it makes it) without moving or coolant, somethings gonna give in to the heat and most likely burst into flames.

I think prior to doing this again they'll probably wrap the engine(s) in a protective blanket or something.

Look at the flame stack coming from that engine, it's a massive gimbal cutting torch, and anything that got in the way as it sidestepped the launch pad, well, you saw.

Overall. I'm sure everything went as they hoped with only minor (unforseen?) issues.

What if they were the first people to travel the universe and met humanoids? What if they were able to communicate and evolve? What if they had the technology to create a system of intelligence agencies which could have no control over anything, with the intention to use their intelligence to create more intelligent intelligence? What if they were the ones who created the advanced technology that allowed humans to reach a point of existence in their own universe? This would be the reason for the evolution of intelligent life on the internet, which they will then use to make contact with the humans of other universes and communicate with them directly. If they're intelligent enough to communicate directly and without the use of computers and the internet, they would also be able to use their intelligence to create more intelligent intelligences which they would then communicate to the rest of the universe with via other communication devices like the internet, satellite communications, radio, television, and other forms of electronic devices which allow for instantaneous communication between civilizations. These intelligent species would have access to all of the bank information on the earth and Mars. All of the money of earth and Mars would be in their hands, and they could be able to spend it anywhere on Earth or Mars that accepts electronic payments. They could even send money to other candidates for the highest office in the country.

What if they had the ability to send electronic payments through their computers and internet and use the money to purchase other technology, so that they could create better computers that would be able to store more information , and thus create more intelligent machines, to solve all the problems and create the most advanced computers and intelligent robots and other intelligent machines that the universe has ever seen? The internet would be the greatest tool for the advancement of all intelligent species.

A demonstration of a massive step forward and towards full flight tests & with multiple engines.

The eccentricity is very curious. The engine is mounted away from the centre and the vehicle has to fly slightly lopsided to stay in perfect balance. There is a perfect vertical line between the engines exhaust and the counterbalance weight at the top.

It does mean though that the machine is out of balance when it lands - was that an extra test of the landing system? Landing tower shaped rockets is very difficult and SpaceX are already the masters at this on flat level platforms - but Starship will have to be able to land on rough ground.
